newsitem.title: UK: British supermarkets to raise music sales share.
newsitem.headline: British supermarkets to raise music sales share.

text.p: Britain's supermarkets could hold 20 percent of the retail market for music and video products by the year 2000 compared with the current level of around 15 percent, according to the "UK Retail Report".
Supermarkets are selling over 400 million stg of music and video products per year in a total market of 2.9 billion stg, the report said.
The four leading chains, Tesco, J. Sainsbury, ASDA and Safeway, sell through over 1,100 stores, it said.
It added that they were likely to increase market share, both by introducing the products into stores which do not yet stock them and by introducing greater price competition.
"A share of 20 percent by the year 2000 is probable and 25 percent is not inconceivable," the report, published by research group Corporate Intelligence on Retailing, said.
The growth in market share is expected to come at the expense of mixed goods retailers such as W.H. Smith and Boots, the report added.
Specialist music and video stores such as HMV, Virgin and Tower Records, "will be less affected if they can avoid being drawn into a price war."
The report said that such stores had moved to attract music enthusiasts with service to encourage browsing through their more extensive ranges.
